xxl.core.collections
Class MappedList<I,O>

java.lang.Object
  java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      java.util.AbstractList<O>
          xxl.core.collections.MappedList<I,O>
Type Parameters:
I - the type of the elements stored by the underlying list.
O - the type of the elements returned by the methods of this list.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<O>, Collection<O>, List<O>
public class MappedList<I,O>
extends AbstractList<O>

The class provides a mapping of a list with a given function. The list to map and the mapping function are internally stored and the indexed access methods get and remove are implemented. Every method that adds or sets elements throws an UnsupportedOperationException (the element to insert cannot be back-mapped). Everytime one of the implemented methods is called on this list the mapping function is invoked with the corresponding element of the internally used list. The iterators returned by the iterator and listIterator methods are also mapped.

The performance of the mapped list depends on the internally stored list that is specified when the mapped list is constructed.

Usage example (1). 

   // create a new list
   
   List<Integer> list = new ArrayList<Integer>();
   
   // insert the Integers between 0 and 19 into the list
   
   for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++)
       list.add(i);
   
   // create a function that multplies every odd Integer with 10 and divides every even
   // Integer by 2
   
   Function<Integer, Integer> function = new Function<Integer, Iteger>() {
       public Integer invoke(Integer o) {
           return o%2 != 0 ? o*10 : o/2;
       }
   };
   
   // create a new mapped list that maps the given list with the given function
   
   MappedList<Integer, Integer> mappedList = new MappedList<Integer, Integer>(list, function);
   
   // print all elements of the mapped list
   
   for (int i = 0; i < mappedList.size(); i++)
       System.out.println(mappedList.get(i));

See Also:
AbstractList, Function, List

Method Detail

add

public void add(I element)
This implementation always throws an UnsupportedOperationException.

Parameters:
element - element to be inserted.
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the add method is not supported by this list.
ClassCastException - if the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this list.
IllegalArgumentException - if some aspect of the specified element prevents it from being added to this list.
IndexOutOfBoundsException - index is out of range (index < 0 || index > size()).

get

public O get(int index)
      throws UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the mapped element at the specified position in this list. This method is equivalent to the call of function.invoke(list.get(index)).

Specified by:
get in interface List<O>
Specified by:

Throws:

remove

public O remove(int index)
         throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
Removes the element at the specified position in this list. Shifts any subsequent elements to the left (subtracts one from their indices). Returns the element that was removed from the list. This method is equivalent to the call of function.invoke(list.remove(index)).

Specified by:
remove in interface List<O>
Overrides:
remove in class AbstractList<O>
Parameters:
index - the index of the element to remove.
Returns:
the mapped element previously at the specified position.
Throws:
IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a MappedList. It can also be used to test the functionality of a MappedList.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
